1 #ifndef SF_BESSEL_H
2 #define SF_BESSEL_H 1
3 
4 #include <complex>
5 
6 #include <emsr/fp_type_util.h>
7 #include <emsr/detail/sf_bessel.tcc>
8 
9 namespace emsr
10 {
11 
12  // Cylindrical Bessel functions (of the first kind)
13 
14  /**
15  * Return the Bessel function @f$ J_{\nu}(x) @f$ of real order @f$ \nu @f$
16  * and argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
17  *
18  * The cylindrical Bessel function is:
19  * @f[
20  * J_{\nu}(x) = \sum_{k=0}^{\infty}
21  * \frac{(-1)^k (x/2)^{\nu + 2k}}{k!\Gamma(\nu+k+1)}
22  * @f]
23  *
24  * @tparam Tpnu The floating-point type of the order @c nu.
25  * @tparam Tp The floating-point type of the argument @c x.
26  * @param nu The order
27  * @param x The argument, <tt> x >= 0 </tt>
28  * @throw std::domain_error if <tt> x < 0 </tt>.
29  */
30  template<typename Tpnu, typename Tp>
31  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<Tpnu, Tp>
32  cyl_bessel_j(Tpnu nu, Tp x)
33  {
34  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<Tpnu, Tp>;
35  return detail::cyl_bessel_j<type>(nu, x);
36  }
37 
38  // Cylindrical Neumann functions
39 
40  /**
41  * Return the Neumann function @f$ N_{\nu}(x) @f$
42  * of real order @f$ \nu @f$ and argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
43  *
44  * The Neumann function is defined by:
45  * @f[
46  * N_{\nu}(x) = \frac{J_{\nu}(x) \cos \nu\pi - J_{-\nu}(x)}
47  * {\sin \nu\pi}
48  * @f]
49  * where @f$ x >= 0 @f$ and for integral order @f$ \nu = n @f$
50  * a limit is taken: @f$ lim_{\nu \to n} @f$.
51  *
52  * @tparam Tpnu The floating-point type of the order @c nu.
53  * @tparam Tp The floating-point type of the argument @c x.
54  * @param nu The order.
55  * @param x The argument, <tt> x >= 0 </tt>.
56  * @throw std::domain_error if <tt> x < 0 </tt>.
57  */
58  template<typename Tpnu, typename Tp>
59  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<Tpnu, Tp>
60  cyl_neumann(Tpnu nu, Tp x)
61  {
62  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<Tpnu, Tp>;
63  return detail::cyl_neumann_n<type>(nu, x);
64  }
65 
66  // Spherical Bessel functions
67 
68  /**
69  * Return the spherical Bessel function @f$ j_n(x) @f$ of nonnegative order n
70  * and real argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
71  *
72  * The spherical Bessel function is defined by:
73  * @f[
74  * j_n(x) = \left(\frac{\pi}{2x} \right) ^{1/2} J_{n+1/2}(x)
75  * @f]
76  *
77  * @tparam Tp The floating-point type of the argument @c x.
78  * @param n The integral order <tt> n >= 0 </tt>
79  * @param x The real argument <tt> x >= 0 </tt>
80  * @throw std::domain_error if <tt> x < 0 </tt>.
81  */
82  template<typename Tp>
83  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp>
84  sph_bessel(unsigned int n, Tp x)
85  {
86  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp>;
87  return detail::sph_bessel<type>(n, x);
88  }
89 
90  // Spherical Neumann functions
91 
92  /**
93  * Return the spherical Neumann function of integral order @f$ n >= 0 @f$
94  * and real argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
95  *
96  * The spherical Neumann function is defined by
97  * @f[
98  * n_n(x) = \left(\frac{\pi}{2x} \right) ^{1/2} N_{n+1/2}(x)
99  * @f]
100  *
101  * @tparam Tp The floating-point type of the argument @c x.
102  * @param n The integral order <tt> n >= 0 </tt>
103  * @param x The real argument <tt> x >= 0 </tt>
104  * @throw std::domain_error if <tt> x < 0 </tt>.
105  */
106  template<typename Tp>
107  inline emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp>
108  sph_neumann(unsigned int n, Tp x)
109  {
110  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp>;
111  return detail::sph_neumann<type>(n, x);
112  }
113 
114  // Cylindrical Hankel functions of the first kind
115 
116  /**
117  * Return the cylindrical Hankel function of the first kind
118  * @f$ H^{(1)}_n(x) @f$ of real order @f$ \nu @f$
119  * and argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
120  *
121  * The spherical Hankel function of the first kind is defined by:
122  * @f[
123  * H^{(1)}_\nu(x) = J_\nu(x) + iN_\nu(x)
124  * @f]
125  * where @f$ J_\nu(x) @c and N_\nu(x) @f$ are the cylindrical Bessel
126  * and Neumann functions respectively (see cyl_bessel and cyl_neumann).
127  *
128  * @tparam Tp The real type of the argument
129  * @param nu The real order
130  * @param z The real argument
131  */
132  template<typename Tpnu, typename Tp>
133  inline std::complex<emsr::fp_promote_t<Tpnu, Tp>>
134  cyl_hankel_1(Tpnu nu, Tp z)
135  {
136  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<Tpnu, Tp>;
137  return emsr::detail::cyl_hankel_1<type>(nu, z);
138  }
139 
140  // Cylindrical Hankel functions of the second kind
141 
142  /**
143  * Return the cylindrical Hankel function of the second kind
144  * @f$ H^{(2)}_n(x) @f$ of real order @f$ \nu @f$
145  * and argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
146  *
147  * The cylindrical Hankel function of the second kind is defined by:
148  * @f[
149  * H^{(2)}_\nu(x) = J_\nu(x) - iN_\nu(x)
150  * @f]
151  * where @f$ J_\nu(x) @c and N_\nu(x) @f$ are the cylindrical Bessel
152  * and Neumann functions respectively (see cyl_bessel and cyl_neumann).
153  *
154  * @tparam Tp The real type of the argument
155  * @param nu The real order
156  * @param z The real argument
157  */
158  template<typename Tpnu, typename Tp>
159  inline std::complex<emsr::fp_promote_t<Tpnu, Tp>>
160  cyl_hankel_2(Tpnu nu, Tp z)
161  {
162  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<Tpnu, Tp>;
163  return emsr::detail::cyl_hankel_2<type>(nu, z);
164  }
165 
166  // Spherical Hankel functions of the first kind
167 
168  /**
169  * Return the spherical Hankel function of the first kind @f$ h^{(1)}_n(x) @f$
170  * of nonnegative order @c n and real argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
171  *
172  * The spherical Hankel function of the first kind is defined by:
173  * @f[
174  * h^{(1)}_n(x) = \left(\frac{\pi}{2x} \right) ^{1/2} H^{(1)}_{n+1/2}(x)
175  * @f]
176  * or in terms of the cylindrical Bessel and Neumann functions by:
177  * @f[
178  * h^{(1)}_n(x) = \left(\frac{\pi}{2x} \right) ^{1/2}
179  * \left[ J_{n+1/2}(x) + iN_{n+1/2}(x) \right]
180  * @f]
181  *
182  * @tparam Tp The real type of the argument
183  * @param n The non-negative order
184  * @param z The real argument
185  */
186  template<typename Tp>
187  inline std::complex<emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp>>
188  sph_hankel_1(unsigned int n, Tp z)
189  {
190  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp>;
191  return emsr::detail::sph_hankel_1<type>(n, z);
192  }
193 
194  // Spherical Hankel functions of the second kind
195 
196  /**
197  * Return the spherical Hankel function of the second kind @f$ h^{(2)}_n(x)@f$
198  * of nonnegative order @c n and real argument @f$ x >= 0 @f$.
199  *
200  * The spherical Hankel function of the second kind is defined by:
201  * @f[
202  * h^{(2)}_n(x) = \left(\frac{\pi}{2x} \right) ^{1/2} H^{(2)}_{n+1/2}(x)
203  * @f]
204  * or in terms of the cylindrical Bessel and Neumann functions by:
205  * @f[
206  * h^{(2)}_n(x) = \left(\frac{\pi}{2x} \right) ^{1/2}
207  * \left[ J_{n+1/2}(x) - iN_{n+1/2}(x) \right]
208  * @f]
209  *
210  * @tparam Tp The real type of the argument
211  * @param n The non-negative order
212  * @param z The real argument
213  */
214  template<typename Tp>
215  inline std::complex<emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp>>
216  sph_hankel_2(unsigned int n, Tp z)
217  {
218  using type = emsr::fp_promote_t<Tp>;
219  return emsr::detail::sph_hankel_2<type>(n, z);
220  }
221 
222 } // namespace emsr
